titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the George B. Darling Papers
titlestmt.author: compiled by Diane E. Kaplan

publicationstmt.publisher: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Thursday January 10, 2019 at 10:26

repository.corpname: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

did.abstract: The papers consist of correspondence, memoranda, reports, notes, and writings which document the professional career of George B. Darling. The papers highlight Darling's role as head of the Division of Medicine at Yale University, 1946-1953, and as director of the Atomic Bomb Casualty Commission, 1957-1972. The papers also include files from Darling's participation in Operation Crossroads as a civilian observer of the atomic testing at Bikini Atoll. There are also photographs from personal travel around the world and papers of various members of the Darling, Smith, and Shaw families. These papers form part of the Contemporary Medical Care and Health Policy Collection.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Gift of George B. Darling, 1976-1987, and the estate of George B. Darling, 1995.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Copyright has been transferred to Yale University for unpublished materials authored or otherwise produced by the creator(s) of this collection. Copyright status for other collection materials is unknown. Transmission or reproduction of materials protected by U.S. Copyright Law (Title 17, U.S.C.) beyond that allowed by fair use requires the written permission of the copyright owners. Works not in the public domain cannot be commercially exploited without permission of the copyright owners. Responsibility for any use rests exclusively with the user.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: George B. Darling Papers (MS 770). Manuscripts and Archives, Yale University Library.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: George Bapst Darling, the son of George Bapst and Alice Emma Smith Darling, was born in Boston, Massachusetts, on December 30, 1905. He attended Boston English High School and Phillips Academy, Andover, Massachusetts. In 1927, he graduated from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and completed work for his doctorate in public health at the University of Michigan in 1931. He married Ann Flora Shaw on June 24, 1931.

Darling worked as a research associate and assistant epidemiologist for the Detroit Department of Health from 1927 until 1932. He then joined the W. K. Kellogg Foundation as associate executive director and served in successively more responsible positions until he was made president of the foundation in 1940, in which capacity he served until 1943. In that year he moved to Washington, D.C. where he became an expert in the administration of medical and scientific affairs. He served as executive secretary of the Committee on Military Medicine of the National Research Council. From 1944-1945, he also served as its vice-chairman of the Division of Medical Sciences. He became executive secretary of both the National Academy of Sciences and the National Research Council in 1945.

In February 1946, Yale University President Charles Seymour asked Darling to accept a new position at the university as director of medical affairs. Seymour envisioned that the director would be a central university administrative officer, with responsibility for the conduct of all university interests represented in its medical school, school of nursing, department of public health, and hospital. The director would be responsible for the budgets of those units and would sit with the Educational Policy Committee of the Corporation, whenever matters ofmedical education were under consideration. Darling accepted this position, but, before moving to New Haven, he went as a non-military observer of Operation Crossroads to witness the atomic bomb testing being conducted on Bikini Atoll during the summer of 1946.

The post-war years were a time of upheaval and reorganization in medicine and health care delivery in the United States. In his years as director of medical affairs at Yale, Darling was confronted with the high costs of medical education and the possibility that the Medical School might not have the funding to function. He lobbied for federal government funding for research and development of medical facilities. There were also discussions of Yale's role in filling the need for training for Connecticut physicians and the desire of some to establish a medical school at the University of Connecticut. Yale needed to redefine its financial relationship with Grace-New Haven Community Hospital (which would become Yale-New Haven Hospital) and help develop methods to provide medical care for indigent patients. On both issues, he worked and became close friends with the hospital's new executive director Albert Snoke. There was also concern in the medical profession over the ethics of Yale School of Medicine faculty treating patients in the various hospital clinics and collecting fees for their services. During the Korean War, Darling sought ways to balance the need to provide medical personnel for the armed forces without disrupting medical education by drafting faculty and students.

Following the hiring of a new dean of the Medical School and the assumption of the Yale presidency by A. Whitney Griswold, the oversight of medical affairs at Yale was reconfigured. With his position eliminated in 1952, Darling became professor of human ecology, a title he held until his retirement in 1974. Darling, however, only taught unti1 1957. In that year, he took what was intended to be a temporary leave of absence from Yale to become the director of the Atomic Bomb Casualty Commission (ABCC) in Hiroshima, Japan. Darling served in this capacity until 1972.

The ABCC was a joint undertaking of the National Academy of Sciences and the Japanese Government. It had been collecting data and publishing reports on the health of atomic bomb survivors since 1948. Darling became the chief administrator for a team of Japanese and American scientists carrying out extensive research on how the atomic bomb blasts over Hiroshima and Nagasaki continued to affect the health and life spans of residents. Periodically, the researchers examined radiation bum survivors, and the results ofthese studies shed new light on the behavior of genes and cancer cells.

Darling stressed the importance of harmony and diversity in this undertaking and believed that the cooperation of the local community was an absolute prerequisite to the ABCC program. Reports and other publications of the commission were published in bi-lingual format. During his tenure, there was an increase in mutual assistance and exchange of personnel with Japanese universities and medical institutions. As director, Darling was involved in labor disputes and negotiations over the share of funding to be provided by each ofthe commission's sponsors, as well as efforts to publicize the commission's work. He was often called upon to appear at ceremonial functions and to escort visiting dignitaries. He and his wife Ann became familiar with Japanese customs and life style and were successful in attracting, acclimating, and retaining young American scientists for the commission's work. In order to further this work, Mrs. Darling co-authored a small book on mastering the art ofthe Japanese tea ceremony.

In recognition of his efforts, Darling was honored with the Japan Medical Association's Supreme Award of Golden Orchid in 1967. He received the United States Atomic Energy Commission citation for meritorious contributions to the nation's atomic energy program in 1970. On leaving Japan in 1972, he returned to Washington, D.C. as a scholar in residence at the John E. Fogarty International Center for Advanced Studies in the Health Sciences, which was sponsored by the National Institutes of Health.

The Darlings were masterful at entertaining guests. They enjoyed travel and visited six of the seven continents. A bon vivant, George Darling attended Rotary International meetings wherever he went. In 1968, Darling was named a Paul Harris Fellow ofthe Rotary Foundation of Rotary International in recognition of his contributions to the international program. For several years the Darlings also enjoyed a summer retreat on Cut-in-Two Island, one of the Thimble Islands off-shore from Branford, Connecticut. In retirement, the couple returned to Hamden, Connecticut, where Darling died at age 89, on March 30, 1995.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The George Bapst Darling Papers consist of correspondence, memoranda, reports, notes, and writings, which document Darling's service with the W. K. Kellogg Foundation, his role as head of the Division of Medicine at Yale University, 1946-1953, and his extended term as director of the Atomic Bomb Casualty Commission, 1957-1972. The papers also include files from Darling's participation in Operation Crossroads as a civilian observer of the atomic testing at Bikini Atoll, photographs from personal travel around the world, and papers of various members ofthe Darling, Smith, and Shaw families.

The papers are arranged in six series, but no one series contains all materials relating to a particular phase of Darling's career. In many instances, when material is divided between series cross references in the series listings direct the reader to other relevant material. Series I, General Files, includes materials, predominately correspondence, from all of Darling's adult life, and includes documents relating to both personal and professional matters. Series II, Yale Files, includes those files specifically created while Darling served as head of the Division of Medicine and while teaching at Yale University, while Series III, Atomic Bomb Casualty Commission Files, contains those files Darling retained from his fifteen years in Japan. Nevertheless, correspondence with personal friends and colleagues in Series I may also be of interest to those studying both the Yale years and ABCC assignment. Series IV, Writings, contains manuscripts, printed copies, and speech notes of Darling's authorship, but correspondence with publishers or concerning arrangements for a speech are found in the first three series. Series V includes personal papers of both George and Ann Darling, as well as papers from other members of both their families. Diaries and memorabilia in this series may be of use to those studying the Darlings' years in Japan, as may be the extensive collection of photographs found in Series VI.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged in six series: I. General Files, 1927-1991. II. Yale Files, 1945-1957. III. Atomic Bomb Casualty Commission Files, 1948-1972. IV. Writings, 1920s-1979. V. Family and Personal Papers, 1805-1995. VI. Photographs, 1813-1995.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The papers are arranged in alphabetical order by personal and corporate name.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The General Files span George Darling's entire professional life and include correspondence and other types of papers, both personal and professional in nature. Many of the correspondents are colleagues and friends in the field of public health.

This series is the best source for information on George Darling's service to the W. K. Kellogg Foundation, but the materials are not Darling's office files from the period. Folder 198 includes a log of Darling's activities during his first year, 1932-1933, at the foundation but no similar material documents his day to day routine during the remainder of his tenure. Rather, his career is reflected in occasional exchanges with various officials of the foundation, such as W. K. Kellogg, Emory Morris, and Stuart Pritchard, particularly at times when Darling or his correspondents were traveling. Through the W. K. Kellogg Foundation files one can learn about the Michigan Community Health Project, which the foundation sponsored. Of note also is the correspondence with Henry F. Vaughan, who, as commissioner of health for Detroit, worked with the foundation. Vaughan later taught at the University of Michigan's School of Public Health, and he continued to correspond with Darling all throughout his career.

The foundation was a training center for numerous health engineers and sanitarians, and there are numerous files for those with whom Darling became acquainted during the Kellogg years. These include Morley Beckett, Al Coburn, Bob Coleman, Herbert Dunsmore, Leon Fox, John E. Gordon, Arthur Hewig, Marshall Jennison, Russell Johnson, Fred Kent, Ray Nebelung, and Clair E. Turner. Their letters describe their experiences during World War II and their later careers in Michigan and around the world. John E. Gordon's letters, for instance, record his experiences in Romania. During the 1980s a group of these Kellogg graduates started a newsletter in which they exchanged news of their pursuits. These newsletters are filed in folder 203.

There is very little in the series, or in the papers, which documents Darling's work for the National Academy of Sciences and the National Research Council in Washington, D.C. Darling's trip to the Pacific to witness Operation Bikini is recorded in letters to his mother Alice Darling and to his wife Ann Shaw Darling.

This series is not rich in material for Darling's years in New Haven. It contains correspondence with various members of the Yale administration and faculty, but most of these exchanges relate to personal or social matters or date from after the Darlings' departure for Japan. There is a sizeable amount of this latter correspondence with Darling's close friend Albert Snoke. During Darling's years in Japan he hosted many visitors from the United States, including many Yale colleagues. Correspondence with them concerns arrangements for their travels but also includes impressions of their visits. This type of correspondence reflects the hospitality for which the Darlings gained renown. Cross-references in the series listing refer to correspondence between 1946 and 1957 in Series II.

Similarly, the series does not contain Darling's official correspondence as executive director ofthe Atomic Bomb Casualty Commission. However, in the Series I files for R. Keith Cannan there is a chronological arrangement of both incoming and outgoing correspondence for the years 1957-1960 which is substantive on ABCC matters. Cannan, who was with the National Research Council, received reports from Darling and kept him informed of decisions made in Washington. There is also some correspondence toward the end ofDarling's tenure with his successor Leroy Allen.

For the most part Darling's associates from ABCC correspond with him only when he is traveling and after his retirement. Kenji Joji, Hiroshi Maki, and Tsutornu (Dutch) Nakayama write of what is happening both in the office and with their family and friends. Hamilton Howard, Seymour Jablon, M. E. Rappaport, and Walter J. Russell, are among the Americans serving with the commission who continue to correspond with Darling after 1972. The United States Atomic Energy files concern arrangements for the citation Darling received.

From 1946 through 1987, the Darlings sent an annual holiday letter to friends and family. These letters summarize projects, travel, and some personal events. They can be helpful in following a major portion of Darling's professional career and life in retirement.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The arrangement of files in this series reflects George Darling's changing role in service to Yale University. The files are divided into two sub-series; the first, the Administrative files, include records Darling kept as director of medical affairs from 1946-1952. The second sub-series, Teaching files, documents courses Darling offered from 1953-1957.

The Administrative files comprise the bulk of the series. They are arranged in alphabetical order by personal and corporate name. The files are indicative of the complex web ofassociations, committees, boards, and departments with whom Darling worked to coordinate medical affairs for the university. For an overview of the many issues Darling faced during his tenure, refer to the files for the Yale University Division of Medical Affairs and to the Yale University Council Committee on the Division of Medical Affairs. The University Council Committee on the Division of Medical Affairs was chaired by Reginald Coombe, and his correspondence delineates his understanding ofvarious situations.

Because Darling was a central administrator in the university, there are substantial files of correspondence and reports with the president (Charles Seymour and A. Whitney Griswold), provost, treasurer, dean of the medical school (C. N. H. Long and Vernon Lippard), and other members of the university administration. Files for the various departments of the medical school, the school of nursing, department of public health, and department of university health include background information needed by Darling for planning purposes, but may also contain discussions of curriculum, budget, facilities, and personnel.

Since Darling's position included oversight of Yale's affiliation with the hospital, there are numerous files for Grace-New Haven Community Hospital, particularly its executive director, Albert Snoke, and its executive committee. During this period the university and the hospital had to reach consensus on various issues involving complex legal and financial matters. These discussions culminated in a joint declaration of policy, a copy of which is included in folder 54, but which is the subject of extensive correspondence and meetings. The files also include notes and preliminary drafts to this declaration.

The sub-series includes files for several medical organizations, both regional and national. Both the files for the Association of American Medical Colleges and National Fund for Medical Education relate to the common concern ofthe period over the high cost of providing training for students. The files for the Connecticut State Medical Society reflect more local concerns on these issues.

Some of Darling's interest in curriculum development is documented in the files for the Committee on the Role of Human Biology and Ecology in University Education (folders 89-90) and the Executive Committee of the Study Unit in Sociology and Medicare (folders 109-110). However, the majority of material concerning Darling's courses in public health and nursing is filed in the sub-series Teaching files. Included are course notes, outlines, readings, and background materials, arranged by course number. Some materials appear to have been used in more than one course. This is particularly true for the class readings, which are, therefore, arranged by topic, rather than by course number and title, at the end of the series.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series includes those materials which Darling chose to keep from his files as executive director of the ABCC. They are not official records, nor are they in any sense comprehensive. Darling's tenure in Japan is well-documented in the published annual reports, newsletters, and other publications of the ABCC, which are available in the Yale University Cushing/Whitney Medical Library. These should be used as primary sources before attempting to locate information in the scantier files available in this series.

The series includes a few folders of background material consisting of copies of official documents from the late 1940s and early 1950s, which concern problems Darling would confront. Of most substance in this series are the six boxes of chronologically arranged outgoing correspondence from 1961-1972, the "Interoffice memoranda," and "Memoranda for the record." Virtually all correspondents included in the listing for Series I, are also recipients of letters in these boxes. Herbert Gardner, executive secretary of ABCC at National Research Council, is major recipient; there is an almost daily letter to him concerning the structure of ABCC, research results, employment issues, and project expansion. Darling directed similar letters to Charles Dunham, the chairman of the medical division of the NRC.

Darling received numerous research proposals from university faculty and staffof other research institutions to undertake joint research ventures. While the files do not include the actual proposal, for the most part, Darling's studied responses to many are indicative of his interests in scientific and medical knowledge. The files include minutes of meetings with Japanese officials and formal reports submitted to the National Research Council on administration and research. There are also notes to staff and others on more mundane matters such as arrangements for sponsored events and entertaining, plans for social activities for American wives, travel plans for visiting dignitaries and friends, and arrangements for the Darlings' own trips. Darling's extensive travels and daily routine are documented in the folders of schedules and itineraries.

A recurring theme in the correspondence and in other files in this series is the effort to work with the government of Japan to plan the future of ABCC operations. The United States wanted Japan to assume more responsibility for the commission, both politically and financially, and there are files dealing with budgetary issues, labor negotiations, and meetings organized to bring Japanese and American officials together to discuss concerns.

The series is also useful for those interested in Japan's perception of the work of the ABCC. Darling had members of his staff prepare translations of local newspaper stories concerning the commission. These translations are in "Press coverage, Japanese." Additional translations are filed in "Correspondence."

Included in the series are a few files relating to Darling's receipt of an award from the United States Atomic Energy Commission and his retirement. A summary of Darling's accomplishments in Japan is included in the honorary volume published in 1972. (Darling's own writing on his term as executive director is included in Series IV.)

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The files are arranged in chronological order.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series includes articles, speeches, and other writings and public statements by George Darling. An individual file may contain notes, drafts, and a printed copy of the work. The earliest item in the series is a work of fiction composed by Darling as a student, while the latest is a tribute to Darling's mentor Henry Vaughan.

Most of the material in the series concerns Darling's years in Japan. Of particular note are the files for Darling's report for Detlev Bronk on the ABCC. This is a lengthy draft, which includes a review of problems confronting the agency and attempts to solve them. There are also numerous brief statements written by Darling for special occasions. The series does not include all the published reports of the ABCC which included remarks by Darling as the executive director. These works are available in the Cushing/Whitney Medical Library.

Additional files in the series relate to Darling's work during the 1940s and early 1950s. The First Eleven Years (folder 11) is a report to the Kellogg Foundation trustees by Darling as president and Emory Morris as general director. It summarizes the foundation's early efforts in the field ofcommunity health and health education. The medical research sponsored by the National Research Council during World War II is detailed by Darling in his chapter in Doctors at War (folder 13). Writings dating from Darling's years as the director of the division of medical affairs of Yale University concern the costs of medical education and research and were written to garner financial and political support for increased funding.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series includes personal papers of George and Ann Darling, as well as correspondence, legal and financial records, and memorabilia of their various Darling, Reed, Shaw, and Whittemore antecedents. Family materials from the nineteenth century encompass memorabilia from Boston, and Concord, Vermont, as well as Civil War era clippings and newspapers from South Carolina, which were collected by Margaret Whittemore in her scrapbook. Personal papers of George Darling's parents, Alice Smith and George B. Darling, Sr., document their lives in Boston, George's military preparedness training in Plattsburg, New York and career with C. F. Hovey and Shepard Stores and Alice's volunteer activities.

Ann Shaw Darling was a conscientious chronicler and her files include both personal and travel diaries, as well as notes on reading and entertaining. Her personal diaries, which span the years 1937 through 1983, contain brief entries recording her life in Michigan, Washington, and New Haven. The entries become more detailed during her first few years in Japan as she describes life in Hiroshima, entertaining for guests, and trips around the countryside. The travel diaries portray the style in which the Darlings traveled as well as the extent of their voyages. The files also include a draft of Ann Darling's memoirs of her years in Japan and a copy of the book she co-authored, How to Be Reasonably Well-Mannered at a Japanese Tea Ceremony .

Personal papers of George Darling begin with appointment books that span almost his entire professional career. Only books from his early years at the W. K. Kellogg Foundation are not included. To some of these volumes Darling added photographs and other bits of memorabilia. Since George Darling did not keep a diary, except during the summer of 1922, these appointment books are useful in following Darling's activities. The series includes memorabilia from Darling's student days and early travels. There are also several folders of souvenirs saved from his participation in Operation Crossroads and memorabilia of special significance from his years in the Far East.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains the Darling's extensive collection of photographs, which includes portraits of family members, images taken on their many trips around the world, and an extensive visual record of their years spent in Japan. The series does not include the occasional photograph of children or family events sent by friends as enclosures in their letters. These photographs remain with their letters of transmittal, primarily in Series I.

The series is arranged by photographic type, beginning with the daguerreotypes and images captured by other early photographic processes. There are also some silhouettes. These early photographs are mainly of Darling, Smith, and Whittemore family members.

A large assemblage of photographic prints includes additional images of family members, colleagues and mends, and portraits and candid shots of Ann and George Darling. Each of these sections is arranged in alphabetical order by name. The remainder of the prints are arranged in chronological order beginning with photographs from George Darling's student days and Operation Crossroads. The vast majority of the prints, however, date from the Darlings' years in Japan. The prints include both formal publicity photographs and more candid shots from official visits of dignitaries to the ABCC, advisory board meetings, social functions, and ceremonial occasions. The prints also include photographs of ABCC staff and their families and of the Darlings' vacation trips.

Slides the Darlings collected are arranged at the end of the series. The earliest slides, those from Yale and Connecticut of the 1950s, were obviously taken by amateur photographers, probably the Darlings themselves. The other slides are primarily those from various trips to the Far East, Latin America, Africa, and Europe. There are occasional slides that the Darlings purchased, but, for the most part, these slides represent the Darling's own views of their travels.

did.unittitle: Daguerreotypes and other early photographic images
Yale, New Haven, and other places in Connecticut
